caseStudies.title: Tesla
caseStudies.tagline: Accelerating the World's Transition to Sustainable Energy

challenge.problem: Electric vehicles were perceived as slow, ugly, impractical, and unappealing. The auto industry was entrenched in internal combustion engine (ICE) technology with little innovation in decades.
challenge.targetAudience: Initially: Wealthy eco-conscious early adopters and tech enthusiasts. Expanded to: Mass market seeking sustainable transportation without compromising performance.
challenge.currentSolutions: Traditional ICE vehicles (gasoline, polluting), hybrids (Toyota Prius - still uses gas), early EVs (Nissan Leaf - limited range, slow charging)
challenge.keyInsight: Start with a high-end sports car to prove EVs can be exciting and desirable, then work down-market. Build from the top to change perceptions.

market.marketSize: $2.8T global automotive market, with EV segment growing from <1% (2012) to 15%+ (2024)
market.targetSegment: Affluent tech enthusiasts and eco-conscious buyers, expanding to mainstream vehicle buyers, plus energy storage customers
market.initialTargetMarket: Silicon Valley wealthy tech workers (2008-2012) - high income, environmental values, early technology adopters
trends: Climate change awareness driving EV adoption
competitors: Traditional automakers (BMW, Mercedes) - slow to EV transition
BYD - Chinese EV giant with cost advantage
Rivian - EV pickup and delivery van focus
Lucid Motors - luxury EV with longer range
opportunities: First-mover advantage in premium EV segment
Vertical integration (battery manufacturing, software)
Supercharger network as competitive moat
Energy storage market (Powerwall, grid-scale)
Autonomous driving as subscription revenue
market.keyInsight: The competitive advantage isn't just the car - it's the ecosystem: Supercharger network, over-the-air updates, and vertical integration of battery technology.

ideation.initialIdea: Build an electric sports car that would be faster and more exciting than gasoline cars, proving EVs could be desirable, not just practical.
pivots: From licensing Lotus chassis → building complete vehicles from scratch (Model S)
From sports car only → sedan, SUV, truck, semi-truck
From selling patents → opening patents to accelerate industry EV adoption
From car company → energy company (solar, storage)
ideation.finalValueProp: Build the best car, and make it electric. Accelerate the world's transition to sustainable energy.
keyFeatures: Frunk (front trunk) thanks to no engine
mvpFeatures: Electric Roadster based on Lotus chassis
uniqueSellingPoints: Best-in-class acceleration and performance
Largest fast-charging network
Continuous improvement via OTA updates
Industry-leading battery technology
Integrated ecosystem (cars + solar + storage)
ideation.keyInsight: Over-the-air updates transform cars from static products into continuously improving platforms, adding features and fixing bugs without dealership visits.

investment-appraisal.fundingNeeded: $7.5M initial Series A, eventually raised $20B+ before profitable
investment-appraisal.revenueModel: Direct vehicle sales (avg $50K per car), plus energy products (Powerwall, Solar), software revenue (FSD subscription $12K or $199/month)
investment-appraisal.initialInvestment: $7.5M Series A led by Valor Equity Partners (2006), including Elon Musk's $6.5M
investment-appraisal.breakEvenTimeframe: First annual profit in 2020 (17 years after founding), after delivering 500K vehicles
investment-appraisal.roi: 2000x+ return from early investment to peak (2021)
investment-appraisal.keyInsight: Vertical integration was expensive but necessary - owning battery production, software, and manufacturing gave Tesla cost advantages and control that competitors couldn't match.

pitch.title: Accelerating Sustainable Energy
pitch.tagline: Build the best car, then make it electric
pitch.traction: 500 Roadsters produced (2008-2012), 2,500 Model S in first year (2012). Now 1.8M+ vehicles delivered annually, leading EV market share.
pitch.team: Elon Musk (CEO, product visionary), JB Straubel (CTO, battery technology), Franz von Holzhausen (Chief Designer). Engineering and design excellence.
pitch.ask: $40M Series B to fund Model S development, build manufacturing capability. Critical funding for scaling from niche Roadster to mass-market sedan.
keySlides: Problem: Cars are polluting, dependent on oil, and not improving
Solution: Electric vehicles are better - faster, safer, cheaper to operate
Product: Model S - premium sedan, 300-mile range, 0-60 in 4.4 seconds
Technology: Proprietary battery packs, over-the-air updates
Market: $2.8T auto market, early in EV transition
Team: Silicon Valley approach to auto manufacturing
pitch.keyInsight: The pitch reframed Tesla as a technology company, not just a car company. Silicon Valley talent and methods applied to manufacturing was the core narrative.

metrics.roi: 2000x+ return from early investment to peak (2021)
metrics.marketImpact: Forced entire auto industry to accelerate EV plans, 1.8M+ vehicles annually, $800B+ market cap at peak

keyLearnings: Start high-end to build brand perception, then go mass market
Vertical integration is hard but creates competitive advantages
Software-defined products enable continuous improvement after sale
First-mover advantage in major transitions (ICE to EV) is massive
Direct-to-consumer sales bypasses dealer resistance to EVs

caseStudies.title: Siemens MindSphere
caseStudies.tagline: The IoT Operating System for Industry

challenge.problem: Industrial companies had massive amounts of machine data but no way to collect, analyze, or act on it in real-time. Equipment failures were reactive rather than predictive, causing unplanned downtime and lost productivity.
challenge.targetAudience: Manufacturing companies, energy producers, and industrial enterprises with connected equipment seeking digital transformation
challenge.currentSolutions: On-premise SCADA systems (siloed, expensive), legacy monitoring (limited analytics), manual inspections (reactive, inefficient)
challenge.keyInsight: Industrial data was trapped in silos. The opportunity wasn't just collecting data - it was creating a platform that could analyze data across equipment types and manufacturers.

market.marketSize: $263B global IoT market in industrial applications by 2024, growing at 20% CAGR
market.targetSegment: Fortune 1000 industrial manufacturers, energy companies, and building automation seeking operational efficiency
market.initialTargetMarket: Siemens' existing industrial customer base (2016) - manufacturing plants with Siemens automation equipment already installed
competitors: GE Predix - similar industrial IoT platform
AWS IoT SiteWise - cloud provider solution
Microsoft Azure IoT - generalist cloud platform
ABB Ability - industrial automation with analytics
opportunities: Base of 2.5M+ Siemens-installed devices to connect
Predictive maintenance market ($4B+)
Energy efficiency regulations driving data needs
Manufacturing skill shortage requiring automation
Digital transformation budgets in industrial companies
market.keyInsight: Siemens' installed base of equipment was the unfair advantage - MindSphere could connect to existing Siemens devices better than any competitor's platform.

ideation.initialIdea: Create a cloud-based IoT platform to collect data from Siemens industrial equipment, analyze it for insights, and enable applications to improve operations
pivots: From proprietary-only → open platform supporting multiple equipment vendors
From manufacturing focus → energy, buildings, transportation
From PaaS only → Marketplace for industrial apps
From cloud-only → hybrid (edge + cloud) architecture
ideation.finalValueProp: MindSphere is the IoT operating system that connects your products, plants, systems, and machines to reveal actionable insights.
keyFeatures: Connect to any industrial equipment (protocols: OPC UA, MQTT)
uniqueSellingPoints: Deep integration with Siemens automation equipment
Industry-specific analytics templates
Hybrid edge-cloud architecture
App store model for industrial solutions
Enterprise-grade security and compliance
ideation.keyInsight: Platform strategy: Don't build all applications yourself. Create APIs and let partners and customers build industry-specific solutions on top of your infrastructure.

investment-appraisal.fundingNeeded: Internal Siemens investment of €500M+ for platform development and go-to-market

useOfFunds.description: App marketplace, developer tools, partner programs
Enterprise sales, industry marketing, customer success

investment-appraisal.revenueModel: SaaS platform subscription: monthly fees based on data volume ($0.50/GB) + device count + app marketplace revenue share (30%)
investment-appraisal.initialInvestment: €500M internal investment from Siemens Digital Industries division
investment-appraisal.breakEvenTimeframe: Expected 5-7 years to profitability due to heavy platform investment, but cross-sells to Siemens automation products improve overall economics
investment-appraisal.roi: Platform enables $10B+ in Siemens automation product sales through digital differentiation
investment-appraisal.keyInsight: For an industrial incumbent, platform ROI isn't just direct revenue - it's about protecting and growing core product sales by adding digital capabilities.

pitch.title: Industrial IoT Platform
pitch.tagline: Connect your machines. Unlock your data. Transform your business.
pitch.traction: Launched in 2016, scaled to 2M+ connected devices by 2021. Now 1000+ enterprise customers across manufacturing, energy, and buildings.
pitch.team: Siemens Digital Industries leadership, combining industrial automation expertise with cloud software talent from acquisitions
pitch.ask: Internal investment to build platform and partner ecosystem before competitors could establish dominance
keySlides: Problem: Industrial data is trapped in equipment silos, unused for optimization
Solution: Cloud-based IoT platform connecting all equipment, regardless of vendor
Market: $263B industrial IoT market, 20% annual growth
Advantage: 2.5M+ Siemens-installed devices as base, deep domain expertise
Business Model: Platform subscription + app marketplace revenue share
Vision: Operating system for Industry 4.0 - the backbone of digital transformation
pitch.keyInsight: The pitch to industrial customers focused on protecting existing CAPEX investments by adding digital capabilities without replacing equipment - a key concern for conservative industrial buyers.

metrics.roi: Platform enables $10B+ in Siemens automation product sales
metrics.marketImpact: 2M+ connected devices, 1000+ enterprise customers, established Siemens as IoT platform leader

keyLearnings: Installed base is an unfair advantage - leverage existing customer relationships
Platform strategy beats building everything - enable partners and customers
Industrial customers need hybrid (edge + cloud) for latency and reliability
Domain expertise matters more than generic cloud capabilities
Digital transformation requires patience - enterprises move slowly

caseStudies.title: Nest

challenge.problem: Thermostats were ugly, confusing, and programmable features were too complex for most users. 90% of people never programmed their thermostats, wasting energy and money.
challenge.targetAudience: Homeowners with central heating/cooling, particularly tech-savvy and design-conscious consumers wanting energy savings without complexity
challenge.currentSolutions: Traditional programmable thermostats (complex interfaces), manual thermostats (no programming), smart thermostats from utilities (ugly, limited features)
challenge.keyInsight: The problem wasn't functionality - it was usability. Great design and machine learning could make energy savings effortless instead of requiring programming.

market.marketSize: $3B smart thermostat market, part of $80B smart home market
market.targetSegment: Homeowners aged 30-55 with tech interest, design appreciation, and environmental awareness. Strong initial adoption in coastal urban areas.
market.initialTargetMarket: Silicon Valley and San Francisco tech workers (2011) - high income, environmental values, early technology adopters
trends: Machine learning becoming practical for consumer devices
competitors: Honeywell/Resideo - traditional thermostats, industrial design
Ecobee - smart thermostat with room sensors
Honeywell Lyric - reactive smart thermostat product
Utility-provided programmable thermostats (ugly, basic)
opportunities: No thermostat had focused on design as differentiator
Energy rebate programs from utilities
Smartphone as control interface (no need for complex on-device UI)
Machine learning could automate scheduling instead of requiring manual programming
Platform expansion (smoke detectors, cameras, doorbells)
market.keyInsight: First smart home device that consumers actually wanted to display in their home. Design wasn't just aesthetic - it was a feature that drove adoption and word-of-mouth.

ideation.initialIdea: Build a beautiful, simple thermostat that learns your schedule automatically, programs itself, and can be controlled from your phone
pivots: From thermostat only → platform of smart home devices
From consumer direct → partnerships with energy utilities
From selling devices → energy services (Rush Hour Rewards)
From standalone → integration with broader smart home ecosystems
ideation.finalValueProp: The Nest Learning Thermostat programs itself in a week and turns itself down when you're away to help save energy.
keyFeatures: Auto-schedule - learns your preferences in a week
Auto-away - detects when you leave, turns down HVAC
Farsight - shows target temperature or time, wakes on approach
mvpFeatures: Beautiful circular design with metal dial
uniqueSellingPoints: Design trophy - looks like premium Apple product
Learns automatically, no programming required
Saves average 10-12% on heating, 15% on cooling
Half of installation done by users (DIY)
Integrates with utilities for rebates and demand response
ideation.keyInsight: Motion sensors were the breakthrough feature - they enabled 'auto-away' which delivered energy savings without user intervention, proving the value proposition immediately.

investment-appraisal.fundingNeeded: $20M initial VC funding, eventually raised $80M before acquisition

useOfFunds.description: Apps, cloud services, machine learning algorithms

investment-appraisal.revenueModel: Hardware sales ($249 MSRP per unit) + installation services + utility partnership revenue (Rush Hour Rewards program)
investment-appraisal.initialInvestment: $20M Series A from Kleiner Perkins, Shasta Ventures, and Google Ventures to fund initial development and launch
investment-appraisal.breakEvenTimeframe: Profitable before acquisition in 2014, with $300M+ annual revenue run rate
investment-appraisal.roi: 40x return from total VC investment to $3.2B acquisition by Google
investment-appraisal.keyInsight: Hardware startups are capital-intensive, but premium pricing and high gross margins (70%+) made Nest attractive. Platform potential expanded the valuation significantly.

pitch.title: The Learning Thermostat
pitch.traction: Sold 40K units in first month (2011), 1M units by 2013. Controlled by 1% of US thermostats within 3 years despite $249 price.
pitch.team: Tony Fadell (CEO, 'father of the iPod'), Matt Rogers (co-founder, former Apple engineer). Hardware and design excellence from Apple alumni.
pitch.ask: $20M Series A to fund product development, manufacturing tooling, and go-to-market for first product launch
keySlides: Problem: 90% of people don't program their thermostats, wasting energy
Solution: Beautiful thermostat that learns your schedule automatically
Market: 250M US thermostats, most outdated, $80B smart home opportunity
Product: Apple-quality design, machine learning algorithms, smartphone control
Business: Premium hardware, high margins, platform potential
Team: Apple alumni who built iPod, understanding of consumer hardware
pitch.keyInsight: The pitch combined Apple-quality design credentials with massive energy savings data. Investors bought into the 'thermostat as the first smart home device' vision.

metrics.roi: 40x return from VC investment to $3.2B acquisition
metrics.marketImpact: 1M+ thermostats sold, defined smart home design standards, launched the modern IoT market

keyLearnings: Design is a feature, not just aesthetics - beautiful products sell themselves
Machine learning can solve usability problems (auto-programming vs manual)
Premium pricing works when product quality and user experience justify it
Partner with utilities for rebates - they benefit from energy savings too
Start with one category-defining product, then expand platform

caseStudies.title: DJI

challenge.problem: Drones were expensive, difficult to fly, and unstable. Industrial and commercial applications were limited by unreliable technology, while consumer market was virtually non-existent due to poor user experience.
challenge.targetAudience: Initially: Hobbyists and RC enthusiasts. Expanded to: Photographers, filmmakers, agriculture, construction, inspection, enterprise/industrial users
challenge.currentSolutions: Custom-built DIY drones (unreliable), military drones (expensive, restricted), RC helicopters (hard to fly, limited payload)
challenge.keyInsight: Flight stability and intelligent flight modes would unlock the market. Making drones easy to fly through software and sensors was the breakthrough needed.

market.marketSize: $30B+ global drone market by 2024, with consumer drones at $5B+ and commercial/industrial at $25B+
market.targetSegment: Photographers and videographers seeking aerial shots, agricultural enterprises for crop monitoring, construction for site surveying, industrial inspection
market.initialTargetMarket: RC hobbyists and photography enthusiasts in China and US (2008-2012) - willing to pay for premium, early adopters of new technology
trends: Smartphone processing power enabling on-board computing
competitors: 3D Robotics - open source approach, failed to scale manufacturing
Parrot - AR Drone for consumers, limited enterprise focus
Autel Robotics - Chinese competitor, lower price
Skydio - US-based, focused on autonomous flight
opportunities: No dominant player in consumer drone space
Film and photography industry ready for aerial capabilities
Agriculture needs crop monitoring at scale
Construction and infrastructure inspection markets underserved
Gimbal technology could stabilize any camera, not just on drones
market.keyInsight: Vertical integration - controlling both hardware and software - allowed DJI to deliver integrated experience that competitors couldn't match with piecemeal solutions.

ideation.initialIdea: Build flight controller systems for RC helicopters, evolving to complete drone systems with stabilized camera gimbals
pivots: From flight controllers only → complete drone systems
From hobbyist components → prosumer photography drones
From consumer only → enterprise/industrial applications
From drones only → camera stabilizers (Ronin series), handheld gimbals
ideation.finalValueProp: DJI drones give anyone the ability to capture stunning aerial imagery easily and safely. Professional tools now accessible to everyone.
keyFeatures: Intelligent flight modes (follow me, waypoint navigation)
Return-to-home on low battery or signal loss
Mobile app control with live HD video feed
mvpFeatures: Flamewheel flight controller for DIY builders
Phantom 1 - ready-to-fly quadcopter with GoPro mount
uniqueSellingPoints: Out-of-the-box experience - no assembly required
Professional quality footage at consumer prices
Intelligent flight modes make flying easy
Camera integration is seamless - not an add-on
Modular design with accessory ecosystem
ideation.keyInsight: The Phantom series was the breakthrough - ready-to-fly with integrated camera. Prior drones required assembly and separate camera purchases, limiting market to hobbyists.

investment-appraisal.fundingNeeded: $500K initial seed from founder's savings, bootstrapped to profitability

useOfFunds.description: Flight control algorithms, gimbal design, camera development
Mobile apps, flight control software, cloud services
Brand building, retail partnerships, enterprise sales

investment-appraisal.revenueModel: Hardware sales (drones $500-$15K+, cameras $1K-$5K, gimbals $200-$3K) + software services (enterprise cloud, data analysis)
investment-appraisal.initialInvestment: $500K from founder Frank Wang's university savings and early revenue from flight controller sales
investment-appraisal.breakEvenTimeframe: Profitable within 3 years of founding, achieved through rapid growth and market dominance
investment-appraisal.roi: Estimated 1000x+ return from early investment to $15B+ valuation
investment-appraisal.keyInsight: Bootstrapping to profitability maintained control and allowed long-term R&D investment. Venture capital came later for scaling, not survival.

pitch.title: The Future of Possible
pitch.tagline: Professional aerial photography, accessible to everyone
pitch.traction: 2008: Started with flight controllers. 2013: Phantom launched, sold 1M units by 2015. Now holds 70%+ global drone market share across consumer and enterprise.
pitch.team: Frank Wang (CEO, engineer), founded in dorm room at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. Engineering-focused culture.
pitch.ask: Initial funding from personal savings, later $10M+ VC to scale manufacturing and expand globally
keySlides: Problem: Drones are hard to fly, unreliable, and limited to hobbyists
Solution: Integrated drone systems that anyone can fly, with professional results
Market: $30B drone market, consumer photography just the beginning
Technology: Proprietary flight control, gimbal stabilization, intelligent flight
Advantage: Vertical integration - hardware, software, manufacturing all in-house
Vision: Drones as tool for photography, agriculture, inspection, rescue operations
pitch.keyInsight: DJI focused on making professional-quality aerial photography accessible to anyone, not just professional filmmakers. This democratization created mass market.

metrics.roi: Estimated 1000x+ return from early investment to $15B+ valuation
metrics.marketImpact: 70%+ global drone market share, defined consumer drone category, expanded to enterprise/industrial applications

keyLearnings: Vertical integration is competitive advantage - control hardware, software, and manufacturing
Make professional quality accessible to mass market - democratization creates larger opportunity
China manufacturing advantage - proximity to supply chain enables rapid iteration
Dual-use strategy: consumer for scale, enterprise for margin expansion
Integration matters: camera built into drone beats add-on camera solution

caseStudies.title: ABB YuMi

challenge.problem: Industrial robots were expensive, dangerous, and required safety cages. They couldn't work alongside humans, limiting automation to large-scale production. Small and medium manufacturers couldn't justify traditional robot investments.
challenge.targetAudience: Electronics assembly, small parts assembly, and light manufacturing where human dexterity was still needed. Expanded to: automotive, food & beverage, pharmaceuticals
challenge.currentSolutions: Traditional industrial robots (fast but dangerous, require caging), manual assembly (slow, inconsistent quality, expensive labor), hard automation (inflexible)
challenge.keyInsight: Making robots safe enough to work directly with humans would unlock automation for millions of tasks that previously required manual labor.

market.marketSize: $14B collaborative robot (cobot) market within $50B+ industrial robotics market, growing at 20%+ CAGR
market.targetSegment: Manufacturers seeking automation for high-mix, low-volume production where traditional robots aren't cost-effective
market.initialTargetMarket: Electronics assembly manufacturers (2015-2017) - high precision requirements, repetitive tasks, labor cost pressures
trends: Rising labor costs in developed markets
Sensor technology enabling safe human-robot collaboration
competitors: Universal Robots - first cobot to market (2008), Denmark-based
Rethink Robotics (Baxter) - failed, shut down 2018
Fanuc CRX series - industrial giant entering cobots
KUKA LBR iisy - German cobot competitor
opportunities: Only 3% of potential tasks are automated today - massive expansion opportunity
Small/medium manufacturers can now afford automation
Cobots can redeploy workers to higher-value tasks
Shorter ROI than traditional robots (1-2 years vs 3-5 years)
Dual-arm robots can do two-handed assembly tasks
market.keyInsight: The market wasn't just replacing humans - it was augmenting human capabilities. Cobots handle repetitive tasks while humans handle judgment and decision-making.

ideation.initialIdea: Build a dual-arm collaborative robot that could safely work alongside humans, performing small parts assembly tasks with human-like dexterity
pivots: From research prototype → commercial product
From single-arm only → dual-arm for two-handed tasks
From general purpose → pre-engineered application solutions
From sales only → Robot Studio simulation software for deployment
ideation.finalValueProp: YuMi is a collaborative dual-arm robot designed to handle small parts assembly with human-level precision while working safely alongside people.
keyFeatures: Dual 7-axis arms with human-like range of motion
Soft, padded surfaces for safe human contact
uniqueSellingPoints: First dual-arm cobot for two-handed assembly
Certified safe for human collaboration (ISO standard)
Compact design fits into existing workcells
Can handle parts as small as 1mm
ABB's global service and support network
Integration with ABB's broader automation portfolio
ideation.keyInsight: Two-handed dexterity was the breakthrough - single-arm robots couldn't handle assembly tasks that humans did easily (holding component while inserting). YuMi's dual arms solved this.

investment-appraisal.fundingNeeded: Internal R&D investment of $50M+ over 5 years, plus go-to-market investment

useOfFunds.description: Robot design, safety certification, vision system development
Production setup, supply chain, quality systems

investment-appraisal.revenueModel: Hardware sales ($40K-$60K per unit) + software (Robot Studio) + annual service contracts (10-15% of hardware price) + application engineering services
investment-appraisal.initialInvestment: $50M+ internal R&D investment from ABB's robotics division, leveraging 40+ years of robotics expertise
investment-appraisal.breakEvenTimeframe: 3-5 years to ROI for customers, ABB's payback on R&D investment through 10+ year product lifecycle and recurring service revenue
investment-appraisal.roi: Enables ABB's position in fast-growing cobot segment, protecting $5B+ robotics business from disruption by cobot specialists
investment-appraisal.keyInsight: For industrial companies, product innovation ROI isn't just direct product margin - it's about protecting core business from disruption and opening new market segments.

pitch.title: You and Me Working Together
pitch.tagline: The world's first truly collaborative dual-arm robot
pitch.traction: Launched at Hannover Messe 2015, global rollout 2016-2017. Now deployed across electronics, automotive, food & beverage, and pharmaceuticals worldwide.
pitch.team: ABB robotics division with 40+ years industrial automation experience, combining Swiss precision engineering with global manufacturing expertise
pitch.ask: Internal investment to pioneer collaborative robotics category, positioning ABB as leader in next-generation manufacturing automation
keySlides: Problem: 97% of manufacturing tasks are manual - traditional robots can't handle them
Solution: Collaborative robots that work safely alongside humans, unlocking new automation opportunities
Product: Dual-arm robot with human-like dexterity, vision-guided, force-sensing for safety
Market: $14B cobot market growing 20%+ annually, only 3% of tasks automated
Advantage: ABB's robotics heritage + global service network + safety certification
Vision: Future of manufacturing is human-robot collaboration, not replacement
pitch.keyInsight: ABB positioned YuMi not as replacing human workers, but as addressing labor shortages and enabling workers to focus on higher-value tasks while cobots handle repetitive work.

metrics.roi: Protects ABB's $5B+ robotics business, positions in $14B cobot market
metrics.marketImpact: Pioneered dual-arm collaborative robotics, established safety standards for human-robot collaboration, expanded automation to small/medium manufacturers

keyLearnings: Safety certification is critical for human-robot collaboration - established new standards
Two-handed dexterity unlocked automation tasks single-arm robots couldn't handle
Ease of programming (teach by demonstration) is as important as robot capabilities
Service and support network is competitive advantage vs. startup cobot companies
Position cobots as augmenting human workers, not replacing them - better adoption
